results.content: Instructor moves a little quickly to follow along with.  The source code files, including the database should be included from the start. results.content: This course is good with a lot of examples/demos. However, Manzoor left annoying Hi alert for a couple of sessions at the first half of the course for no reason. Also, he didn't explain completely some concepts, for example, modules. Can we have multiple modules in our projects?  etc. This course is too short to cover all these important details. The best section of the course is Section 9 "Routing And Views". Manzoor has done a great job to explain us the Directory Structure.
results.content_html: This course is good with a lot of examples/demos. However, Manzoor left annoying Hi alert for a couple of sessions at the first half of the course for no reason. Also, he didn't explain completely some concepts, for example, modules. Can we have multiple modules in our projects? etc. This course is too short to cover all these important details. The best section of the course is Section 9 "Routing And Views". Manzoor has done a great job to explain us the Directory Structure.

results.content:
After the first project thing really kick off and the course gets a lot better.

I had a little Difficulty setting up the entity association which made me lose a lot of time.
but after that i was fine... if you tune up this course please review this point 

and add the !#/ for the angular hashed due to 1.6.5 update 

aside from that Manzoor ! Thank you. I've learned a large deal and i'm only Halfway done !!!

:)
results.content_html:
After the first project thing really kick off and the course gets a lot better.

I had a little Difficulty setting up the entity association which made me lose a lot of time.
but after that i was fine... if you tune up this course please review this point

and add the !#/ for the angular hashed due to 1.6.5 update

aside from that Manzoor ! Thank you. I've learned a large deal and i'm only Halfway done !!!

:)

results.content: The course is very well structured and introduce you to all major concepts from AngularJS. Author is clear and to the point and he explained concepts thoroughly. Honestly it took me a couple of chapters to get in sync with the author because of his lazy naming conventions used across this course. But overall it was a very great learning experience. It would be nice if there is a quiz at the end of every chapter, just a suggestion though.
results.content_html: The course is very well structured and introduce you to all major concepts from AngularJS. Author is clear and to the point and he explained concepts thoroughly. Honestly it took me a couple of chapters to get in sync with the author because of his lazy naming conventions used across this course. But overall it was a very great learning experience. It would be nice if there is a quiz at the end of every chapter, just a suggestion though.

results.content:
Without a doubt, this is the most helpful course that I've taken on Udemy, to-date.  I needed a course that wouldn't just show me HOW AngularJS works, but would also tell me WHY I should to use, using real-world scenarios.  If you're looking for a "Hello World" example, or just a list of directives to use within the framework, then this isn't for you.  This is meant for people who are very serious about diving into it and figuring out how it can be incorporated into real projects.

If you're an MVC (or even a web forms) developer and want to know how to use AngularJS, as well as how to have it interact with WebAPI calls, then this is exactly what you're looking for!  Before I had even finished the course, I was already bragging about the usefulness to my coworkers and was even able to hold a real conversation about AngularJS during an interview that I had, the following week.

If you really want to get deep into AngularJS, please give this course a try.  Manzoor is amazing and compared to other courses that I have seen (and even taken) on Udemy, this is definitely the best.

results.content:
After watching the first ten modules from the preview of this course, I can say that if you're a .NET developer with some MVC experience, this is the best series you will find on getting started with AngularJS. It beats courseware on Pluralsight due to the simple demos. There are still things I'd like to see:
1. Show me how to integrate jQuery within Angular JS.
2. Show me how you'd perform a POST
This course makes me want to look deeper into the courses from Manzoor. Thanks Udemy!

results.content: This call was very informative.  The only issue I ever had was setting up between lectures, because the teacher did not show every single step in some of his lectures.  This makes the course much shorter and delivers new information quickly.  It is sometimes easy to get confused on the other hand.  I would recommend this course to anyone who knows ASP but not angular.

This makes the course much shorter and delivers new information quickly. It is sometimes easy to get confused on the other hand. I would recommend this course to anyone who knows ASP but not angular.

results.content:
I was a little concern about the accent because it is a little on the heavy side, but after the 2nd 3rd lesson you start getting used to it and once you get engaged with the content and concepts, you don't even notice it. So if you are a little worry about that, don't mind it, he gets much more fluent after the first couple videos.
The content itself is pretty good as well; It doesn't go too deep into any concept but he covers enough ground for you to understand the techniques at hand, and you can keep digging deeper on your own on the ones that interest you the most.
Overall, I enjoyed this course.

results.content: Love that you go through practical application of Angular, but need more explanations of how/why it works.  Excellent tour of Angular, though.  You share some really great tips on working with local/session variables as well.  Thank you for doing that.  I'd appreciate some tips on how we can make them more practical, especially for saving things like usernames and passwords.
results.content_html: Love that you go through practical application of Angular, but need more explanations of how/why it works. Excellent tour of Angular, though. You share some really great tips on working with local/session variables as well. Thank you for doing that. I'd appreciate some tips on how we can make them more practical, especially for saving things like usernames and passwords.

results.content:
Ok, so after finishing the course, I cannot say that I did not learn some stuff, but can I say that I am ready to build an Enterprise level applications or any application that is a more than just CRUD operations? NO WAY. I just learned the basics of AngularJS. The instructor is not showing real world scenarios. The instructor tends to cut videos and continue the same stuff in the next video. I do not get the point? 

Anyways, stay away from this course you can learn all this and even more on your own or just buy a different course.

results.content:
Thanks for another great course. I cannot wait for you to apply all the concepts in whole application as you always do. That really helps to understand how things are put together.

Hopefully, you will be including the following topics/items in future sessions, especially when you get into writing a whole application:
 - Code Sample at end of each section
 - Best practices using Angular, EF, Web API and WCF.
 - Several Views (ng-view) – with menu options

Again, thanks for taking the effort to do this so expected course and for explaining things so clearly.

Andy
